title: As a parent, how did you feel sending your child off on their first day of kindergarten? How did that first day go for you? - Quora

response.answer_text: I wasn’t prepared for an emotional scene as I was leaving my 3 year old at preschool the first time. I thought he would be fine and I would come back in 3 hours to get him. But he cried a lot and didn’t want me to leave. What should I do, I wondered. The teachers were accustomed to this behavior which many children experience as they separate the first time from mom to stay on their own at school. The staff knew how to handle it. They said, we’ll take care of everything, he will be ok. You just go on home. I did what they told me to, but I worried about him and felt like maybe I was abandoning him. When I went to pick him up, no crying, super happy to see me, all was well. He struggled9 with the emontional separation for about a week, but I noticed some of the older children in his (Montessori) class greeted him and led him off to do some of the works. It was gratifying to see him with other children who cared about him. It was all part of his development and part of his journey toward independence. He was fine just like 99.9,% of thenother kids who don’t want mom to go. Handing off a crying child to a caring, experienced professional doesn’t need to worry you. It is part of being a good mom.

It was great. I have a very large family, so we would leave our children with their aunt or grandma sometimes, so they could play with their cousins and they could get used to the idea that we can leave them with somebody and we will come back later. Our children went to the preschool at the school where they were going to go to kindergarten. They had a half day option, and they could go 2 or 3 days a week. That way they got used to going there, and got to know the children in their age group. When Kindergarten started, it wasn’t a huge difference for them. I think people who have difficulty with this never leave their child with anyone until the first day of kindergarten, and it ends up being a huge traumatic thing, when it really doesn’t have to be. Getting your child used to staying with someone else ahead of time makes the transition to kindergarten much easier.

First, be excited for the child- kids can tell when you’re not comfortable and they can feed off of that. Talk about all the positive stuff that they will encounter, the new friends- maybe even learn new games. Encourage the kid to have fun, be themselves and that you cannot waitnto hear everything when you pick them up. Hug them- love them- send them to school. Then- get to the car. Take a deep breath! It will be okay. The silence isn’t bad- if it is the only child you have- you will soon remember how you had hobbies or even go back to school yourself-but you’ll rediscover yourself. Plan your time to get everything done, and prepared for when your child returns. Meet with friends, go exercise, clean up and read all day- uninterrupted. Or go shopping, get a mani- pedi. Have a dance party alone and just turn the music up loud. The possibility is endless. Then go get your child- listen to everything, ask questions, laugh and breathe. You’ll enjoy it. It will get better as you learn you and your new found chapter in life. If you have other children in the home- it will look different- but at least you’ll still be busy handling the other child in your care. But know that it will be okay.

I was excited when my kids went off to kindergarten. Each and every one of them. I walked them to class met the teacher and in my mind I said “hell yeah! I got time on my hands.” What am I going to do 1st? My kids weren't the type to cry and beg me not to leave them there. They enjoyed every minute of school. They loved it and so did I..

Being a Nursery school teacher myself made it a lot easier for me, but because it is Your child, you do have that sense of loss and fear that your child will miss you too much or won’t know what to do. It’s an awful conflict, you know you are doing the right thing, but for a Mother's heart, it just feels wrong! Then when you see them after the first day, all happy and playing, smiling, you know everyting will be OK! Junior will thrive! A new life has begun!

I felt proud, anxious, sad, happy, worried… (you get the idea) All the emotions stayed at a lower intensity for the remaining of the whole eternal morning, until I picked them up afterwards. Then only the positive feelings stayed. It was really a great day.
